intro: Rubus fissidens, commonly known as the fissured blackberry, is a species of bramble native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that are typically dark purple to black when mature. It thrives in moist, wooded areas and is often found in the understory of forests. Botanically, it belongs to the Rosaceae family and is closely related to other blackberry and raspberry species.
